response.answer_text: Realistically yes, all people who employ thinking and are able to reflect in some shallow capacity on their ability to think qualify as philosophers, because you don’t have to be good at something to be called a practitioner - you just have to try. It’s like running and being able to see - are all people runners and seers? Yeah, technically, they are actually. Of course, there are a lot of other factors that people consider in a personal sense when they decide whether or not another person qualifies as a philosopher - I do this very thing, because I have pretty strict standards for what counts as good thinking. I would say that most ‘good philosophers’ (oh the irony) would display a proclivity to make a distinction between a philosopher as someone who thinks about the world and the relationship they have with it, even in a superficial capacity - everyone is this type of philosopher - and one who engages with the world in a carefully considered, analytical approach that incorporates at least some elements of valid reasoning & error-checking.

The word philosopher means lover of wisdom, so probably not all people are philosophers, but in theory all people could be lovers of wisdom if they would value wisdom as higher achievement one could strive for. All people could philosophize, meaning engaging into meaningful dialogue with other people, or even contemplating different life issues they encounter in daily situations or abstract thinking.

In a most amazing tale, written during the romantic age of great musical compositions, at the dawn of an atrocious conflict that would have shattered the entire planet, Friedrich Nietzsche wrote: mankind is made of sleep-walkers, enslaved to their needs; only few of them are capable to be awakened. And the awakening is hailed with a lion’s roar, that is heard from league of distance. This is a peculiar style of philosophy many theoricists have banned as “mere literature”: it is classified in the vitalistic trend some thinkers have enabled themselves to during the last years of eighteenth century in Europe. Although philosophy means a lot of things, this procedure is open and talk straight to the heart of our matter: theories of knowledge, debates and quarrels upon what is available for humans mind, endless fights to list the quality of things and excruciating argues among scholars to demonstrate the existence of God may set the difference between what true philosophy is and what it is just “mere literature”, a game for losers. A waste of time. To answer clearly and exhaustively enough to your question, one must first define what philosophy is: when you stick to the root of this greek word, everyone is entitled to be “lover of wisdom”, each one of us can be questioned upon reality and give a personal answer to that, no matter how fit the answer is for the Academy. When philosophy becomes a matter for specialists, its language gets strict and rules too hard to follow, then something is missing: the joyful insight that makes someone realize existence is what it is ignites great meditations, profound and selfless. And I am personally persuaded that everybody can be caught in one of these moments.

Depends on what you mean by “philosopher.” I think all people are, at least early on, interested in philosophical questions (kids ask the darnedest questions, and not just about sex and Santa Claus!). But most seem to become less interested as they age, perhaps consoling themselves with self-serving rationalizations about the uselessness of philosophy. Pity, in my opinion. Few, of course, go on to devote considerable time and effort to exploring those early questions.

response.answer_text: Aren't we all philosophers? [Long answer, worth reading.] Indeed all philosophize. Anyone who reflects on anyting is philosophizing. That doesn’t make everyone a philosopher. It is somewhat like this. Many people have seen waterfalls and cataracts. They say things like: “Oh, how wonderful!” “That’s beautiful! “ “oh my!” “It is simply fantastic!” But here is how Robert Southey wrote about a cataract in the 1820s: "How does the water Come down at Lodore?" ……. ……. From its fountains In the mountains, Its rills and its gills; Through moss and through brake, It runs and it creeps For a while, till it sleeps In its own little lake. And thence at departing, Awakening and starting, It runs through the reeds, And away it proceeds, Through meadow and glade, In sun and in shade, And through the wood-shelter, Among crags in its flurry, Helter-skelter, Hurry-skurry. Here it comes sparkling, And there it lies darkling; Now smoking and frothing Its tumult and wrath in, Till, in this rapid race On which it is bent, It reaches the place Of its steep descent. The cataract strong Then plunges along, Striking and raging As if a war raging Its caverns and rocks among; Rising and leaping, Sinking and creeping, Swelling and sweeping, Showering and springing, Flying and flinging, Writhing and ringing, Eddying and whisking, Spouting and frisking, Turning and twisting, Around and around With endless rebound: Smiting and fighting, A sight to delight in; Confounding, astounding, Dizzying and deafening the ear with its sound. Collecting, projecting, Receding and speeding, And shocking and rocking, And darting and parting, And threading and spreading, And whizzing and hissing, And dripping and skipping, And hitting and splitting, And shining and twining, And rattling and battling, And shaking and quaking, And pouring and roaring, And waving and raving, And tossing and crossing, And flowing and going, And running and stunning, And foaming and roaming, And dinning and spinning, And dropping and hopping, And working and jerking, And guggling and struggling, And heaving and cleaving, And moaning and groaning; And glittering and frittering, And gathering and feathering, And whitening and brightening, And quivering and shivering, And hurrying and skurrying, And thundering and floundering; Dividing and gliding and sliding, And falling and brawling and sprawling, And driving and riving and striving, And sprinkling and twinkling and wrinkling, And sounding and bounding and rounding, And bubbling and troubling and doubling, And grumbling and rumbling and tumbling, And clattering and battering and shattering; Retreating and beating and meeting and sheeting, Delaying and straying and playing and spraying, Advancing and prancing and glancing and dancing, Recoiling, turmoiling and toiling and boiling, And gleaming and streaming and steaming and beaming, And rushing and flushing and brushing and gushing, And flapping and rapping and clapping and slapping, And curling and whirling and purling and twirling, And thumping and plumping and bumping and jumping, And dashing and flashing and splashing and clashing; And so never ending, but always descending, Sounds and motions for ever and ever are blending All at once and all o'er, with a mighty uproar, - And this way the water comes down at Lodore. You will see the difference between a normal reaction and a real poet’s reaction. So it is with philosophizing. Peace! 5 March 2019

No, not in the sense of living a life of a Socrates or a Spinoza, sacrificing anything and everything in order to find and live the truth that they’ve found. On a lower level, we all do, it seems, try to figure out life. It’s in our own best interest; but I would argue that most people make the minimum effort, find some relatively comfortable path to follow, and they’re done. No more seeking a better or higher way for them.

I would say that all people are potentially philosophers, because even very small children ask philosophical questions. However, Western Philosophy is a very specific literature, with very specific authors with very specific ideas and vocabularies. Only scholars who spend years studying the Great Philosophers can rightly be candidates for the title of philosopher. Of course, metaphorically we are all philosophers, poets, musicians and artists just as we are. Yet I presumed the question was more literal.

Yes. I assume that everyone who writes ir a writer and who dance is a dancer. So there is no way that a person won't ever ask to itself at least Practical Philosophy questions, as “How can I be happy?” or “How I must behave with other people?”. Only a person who always use rigid rules and never doubt can be not a philosopher. Philosophy is critically thinking. For life itself people question inside their minds and with others.

Nor does a work that you read in answer to another mans/woman's work become a part of philosophy just because it was written with that intent or within this particular field. Many want to be counted, and very few are in reality the givers of great works.

Yes we all are. But the problem is just people don’t realise things that are essential because they are absorbed in the materialistic world. They think money is the key to the universe. But if they are again reminded who they are, they can change for good. We are all philosophers in the sense that we need to find out our personal truth.

No. Yes, there are some persons who like to think about philosophical questions of life, living, the world, the universe and the rest. But not everybody has this inclination. Just like not everybody is into square dancing… Makes sense? ;)
